posts.name: Erdem Tellioglu
posts.cooked:
Hi everybody,

This year, we decided to use pneumatic pistons in our gripper system to grab cones and cubes. We then designed 3 different systems in order to have some alternatives in case there is a problem with our current gripper. Unfortunately, we had some specific problems in those 3 designs that made me create a thread to get some help from you. First of all, let me share those designs and explain you the problems we had with each of them.

First Design: image 830√ó612 54.1 KB

image 830√ó612 54.1 KB

image 830√ó612 54.1 KB

This was our first gripper design (without the parts for grabbing in the front side; since the problem is not related to grip, I didn‚Äôt include it). Basically, the problem with this design was that when we activate the piston, and it pushes forward, we aimed to translate this force in a perpendicular direction that it pushes the arms of the gripper to the sides. However, since the angle of translation of force is 90 degrees, this design didn‚Äôt work.

Second Design:

image 738√ó533 72.3 KB

image 738√ó533 72.3 KB

image 738√ó533 72.3 KB

This is our second mechanism for gripper (again without the parts for grabbing in the front side) which we designed as an alternative to the first one. As you can see, we decided to rotate the piston and eliminate the need for translation. However, the problem with this design is that when we activate the piston the tube of it extends beyond the frame perimeter from the left side and since we also extend this arm from the front side this mechanism violates the rule for extending to multiple sides.

Third Design:

image 1055√ó447 79.6 KB

image 1055√ó447 79.6 KB

image 1055√ó447 79.6 KB

This is our third design. This design is similar to our first design, but we adjusted the angle between the rail and piston by making it 45 degrees instead of 90 in order to ensure that the force from the piston can be translated and thus push the arms of the gripper along the rail. However, the challenge with this design was that the arms move along the rails not towards each other (as we expected in the first design), but in an angled direction, which makes it really difficult to adjust the squeezing of cones and cubes using arms.

These are our designs which we had previously thought at least one of them will work and since it‚Äôs not the case I would really appreciate if you have some ideas and thoughts about alternative mechanism or upgrades on these previous ones?

I‚Äôm also sharing the full design of our robot for you to better understand the mechanism.

image 738√ó660 94.7 KB

image 738√ó660 94.7 KB

image 738√ó660 94.7 KB

posts.name: Drakxii
posts.cooked: Instead of attaching the piston arms to the bolt mounting the grabbers, you could extend the grabbers past that bolt and mount the piston arms to that.  If the mounting bolt is fixed, when you pull the piston in the grabbers would open and when it‚Äôs pushed out the grabber would close.

posts.name: Penn Carbo
posts.cooked: I think your second one is best if you‚Äôre trying to avoid a complete redesign, since the (as you said) first one can‚Äôt transfer force properly and the third one seems to just be the same problem but with better force and worse motion. If the problem is that the second one is wider than your robot, you could consider just only opening in the community or loading zone, as the multiple direction extensions don‚Äôt apply there. It‚Äôs not ideal and it requires your drivers to be very diligent, but it could work.
